awd_titl_txt: FMSG: Biologically Assembled and Recycled Construction and Structural Materials (BRICS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Cement and concrete building materials are ubiquitous in the built environment but require high energy, time, labor, and material resources to manufacture. Cement manufacturing necessitates high temperature processing, and is associated with 5-9 percent of anthropogenic carbon emissions.  Concrete, which includes cement and fine and coarse aggregates, requires increasingly scarce materials.  Most cement and concrete building materials cannot be reused or recycled.  In this Future Manufacturing Seed Grant (FMSG) project, the investigators will develop reusable and recyclable modular building materials that are produced by microorganisms via a processes known as biomineralization and biocementation.  Graduate and undergraduate students will participate in this project and gai interdisciplinary training in ecomanufacturing, civil engineering, material science and microbiology.  High school teachers will also be engaged in the research project and will develop classroom activities based on biocemetation.  K-12 classroom materials will be widely disseminated.  In addition, instructional materials in ecomanufacturing will be developed and disseminated to a local community college.

The investigators will pursue the first steps in a new paradigm for the eco-manufacturing of building and infrastructure materials that overcomes the high material, time, energy, and labor needs of traditional concrete manufacturing. They will use microbes to construct, reversibly interlock (enabling re-use), break down and recycle modular building materials (MBMs). These MBMs could be assembled to build load-bearing structures and infrastructure. When the structures are no longer wanted, the MBMs could either be separated and then interlocked again in a different structure or broken down and recycled for the next generation of MBMs. In this Seed Grant, the investigators will explore four primary challenges to identify the potential for microbes in eco-manufacturing building materials: (1) Constructing MBMs using fungi and/or bacteria, (2) Reversibly interlocking the MBMs using biomineral glues, (3) Breaking down the MBMs to their components using fungal metabolisms, and (4) Recycling the components into new MBMs.

This project is jointly funded by the Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation Division of the Engineering Directorate, the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), and the Biological Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The manufacturing of building and infrastructure materials heavily relies on cement and concrete. Cement requires high energy, time, labor, and material resources to manufacture. Cement manufacturing is burdened with a high carbon footprint (5-9% of anthropogenic CO2 emissions)​​. The impressive resource needs and limited re-use and recycling of cement and concrete are at odds with a resource-limited future. The central goals of the ‘Biologically assembled and Recycled Construction and Structural Materials’ (BRICS) project were to improve upon cementitious building materials through eco-manufacturing biocemented modular building materials. The major scientific objectives were organized around four objectives: the construction, interlocking, breakdown, and recycling of modular building materials.

We advanced knowledge about the construction of biocemented materials through:

(i)     Bio-trapping ureolytic bacteria using silane-coupling agents such as 3-aminopropyl-methyl-diethoxysilane (i.e., APMDES). This process localized Sporosarcina pasteurii (S. pasteurii) through electrostatic attraction between bacteria and APMDES-treated sand surfaces. A ‘scaffold’ of bacteria enabled more rapid biocementation and development of strength during biocementation compared with non-treated controls.

(ii)   The use of fungal scaffolds. Neurospora crassa (N. crassa) formed a scaffold that could either self-mineralize or support mineralization by ureolytic bacteria (i.e., S. pasteurii). Our studies identified conditions that impact N. crassa growth and ureolysis. We also learned that calcium carbonate biomineral characteristics (i.e., size, location within the scaffold, microscale modulus and hardness) depend on whether the ureolytic organism is N. crassa or S. pasteurii.

We advanced knowledge about the interlocking of materials through the development of calcium carbonate-reinforced biopolymer adhesives. Specifically, we found that calcium carbonate precipitated in association with microbial- or enzymatic-sources of urease increased the adhesive strength of biopolymer adhesives. These adhesives have potential sustainability benefits compared with traditional, higher-VOC adhesives. We investigated durability characteristics of these adhesives, including exposure to water and freezing through elevated temperatures. Finally, we investigated the influence of organics (i.e., bovine serum albumin) on the microscale material properties of calcium carbonate biomineral.

We advanced knowledge about the breakdown and recycling of biocemented materials using fungi. Certain species of fungus can produce organic acids with the potential to break down calcium-containing biomineral. We found that Aspergillus niger (A. niger) can solubilize calcium carbonate. Further, media from A. niger cultures can promote calcium leaching from biomineralized structures.

We extended the impact of our work through mentoring graduate and undergraduate students, of whom many identified as part of one or more underrepresented communities. Our team engaged K-12 students in outreach activities and also mentored K-12 teachers in participating in biomineralization studies. We also introduced a new class to MSU: The ArtScience of Sustainable Building Materials and Processes. This class included graduate and undergraduate engineering and art students. Teams of students designed an ArtScience exhibition that was on public display for two weeks in December 2023.
